title: 108_s995
content:
The "Child Nutrition Initiatives Act of 2003" includes provisions for healthier schools, grants for farm-to-cafeteria projects, state administrative expenses for school breakfast programs, nutrition education, and an effective date for the Act. The Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to include incentives for healthier schools by increasing reimbursement rates for schools that improve the nutritional value of meals, specifically by increasing the consumption of fluid milk. The Secretary will establish criteria for schools and institutions to increase consumption of fluid milk, fruits, and vegetables. Approved plans may set goals for increasing consumption and improve accessibility. The Secretary will establish criteria for schools and institutions to increase consumption of fluid milk, fruits, and vegetables, improve accessibility, presentation, and promotion of these items, tailor food services to the population and area demographics, and provide increased standard serving sizes. The Secretary will establish criteria for schools to increase consumption of fluid milk, fruits, and vegetables through improved packaging, flavor variety, and merchandising. Administration will consider relevant research and consult with food service and nutrition professionals. The Secretary will increase reimbursement rates for meals under the program to reflect additional costs incurred by schools in promoting consumption of fluid milk, fruits, and vegetables. Rates will be raised by 2 to 10 cents per meal based on criteria established by the Secretary. The Secretary will raise reimbursement rates for meals under the program by 2 to 10 cents per meal based on established criteria. SEC. 102. GRANTS TO SUPPORT FARM-TO-CAFETERIA PROJECTS. Section 12 of the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act is amended to provide grants for farm-to-cafeteria projects, aiming to improve access to local foods in schools and institutions. Nonprofit entities and educational institutions can receive competitive grants for activities like purchasing equipment, procuring foods, and providing training. The Secretary will prioritize farm-to-cafeteria projects that procure local foods from small- and medium-sized farms, support nutrition education activities involving school children in agriculture projects, and establish a sustained commitment to these projects in the community by linking schools, producers, parents, and stakeholders. Technical assistance will also be provided. The Secretary may provide technical assistance and share information on farm-to-cafeteria projects. Grants will be given to private nonprofit entities and educational institutions to establish and carry out these projects. The maximum grant amount for farm-to-cafeteria projects is $100,000. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 75%, and the grantee must provide matching funds. The grantee must provide a share for the cafeteria project in cash or in kind, evaluated fairly. The non-Federal share can come from State, local, or private sources. A farm-to-cafeteria project can only be supported by a single grant not exceeding 3 years. The Secretary must evaluate the projects by January 30, 2008. The Secretary shall evaluate and report on funded projects, with $10,000,000 transferred annually for implementation until 2007. The Secretary is authorized to receive and use transferred funds without further appropriation for carrying out the subsection. TITLE II--SCHOOL BREAKFAST AND RELATED PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. STATE ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES.

Minimum grant for State under Child Nutrition Act of 1966 increased to $200,000. Extension of deadline to 2008.

SEC. 202. SPECIAL SUPPLEMENTAL PROGRAM FOR WOMEN, INFANTS AND CHILDREN. The text chunk discusses the full funding and reauthorization of the special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children under the Child Nutrition Act of 1966. It emphasizes the need for full funding in fiscal year 2004 and subsequent years, as well as amending certain sections of the Act to extend deadlines to 2008. The text chunk amends the Farmers' Market Nutrition Program under the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 by updating deadlines to 2008 and making changes to specific paragraphs. The text chunk updates funding allocations for the Farmers' Market Nutrition Program, with specific amounts allocated for each year from 2003 to 2007. The funds transferred under subparagraph (A) for the Farmers' Market Nutrition Program shall be accepted and used without further appropriation. The funds remain available until expended. SEC. 203. NUTRITION EDUCATION AND TRAINING. Section 19(i) of the Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to allocate $27,000,000 annually from 2003 to 2007 for the Secretary of Agriculture to carry out the section. Grants to each State under subparagraph (A) are based on 50 cents per child enrolled in schools, with a minimum grant of $200,000 per fiscal year. The Act and its amendments will be effective starting on October 1, 2003.
